content.webTitle: Two red cards as Wallabies upset All Blacks in final Bledisloe Cup Test

fields.headline: Two red cards as Wallabies upset All Blacks in final Bledisloe Cup Test
fields.bodyText: The talking points may centre around two red cards but the Wallabies will disembark their Bledisloe Cup rollercoaster in the knowledge this new generation can beat the All Blacks. One week after that record 43-5 humiliation in Sydney, Australia chipped away at their trans-Tasman rivals in Brisbane, leading, then conceding, and eventually outlasting a team that had seven days ago consigned them to a harrowing place indeed. The 24-22 result was as close numerically as it was in balance of play, and full-time beckoned for the Australians long before they heard the sweet sound of the final whistle. The boot of Reece Hodge had squeezed Dave Rennie’s side into a 17-15 lead with 10 minutes remaining at Suncorp Stadium, before Taniela Tupou ran over in the 75th minute and Hodge added the extras for a nine-point buffer. Had they had a say, the Wallabies would have stopped the count there. But the All Blacks are known for gaining key territory in tight contests, and made no exception here when Tupou Vaa’i scored his first Test try with a minute on the clock. Jordie Barrett’s conversion closed the deficit to two points, and there the scoreboard stood as a standpost of Rennie’s first win since succeeding Michael Cheika as coach. Saturday night’s fourth Test was a textbook contradiction of a dead rubber, a chaotic thriller that finished with 14 men apiece after referee Nic Berry showed two red cards in line with rugby’s high-tackle rules designed to minimise head injuries. Both hosts and visitors were depleted before half-time, as promising Wallabies debutant Lachie Swinton followed All Blacks forward Ofa Tu’ungafasi to the sheds for near-identical high tackles. Replays showed Tu’ungafasi had hit Tom Wright – who scored the opening try with his first touch of a Test football – on the chin. With no mitigating factors, Berry gave the marching orders. It should have provided a pivotal advantage, but the Wallabies’ failure to sufficiently capitalise allowed New Zealand to match Hodge’s early penalty – Noah Lolesio’s replacement at five-eighth kicked four penalties for a total five from seven. They took that 8-8 scoreline into half-time with 13 players on the field. The first to go was Swinton, who replicated Tu’ungafasi’s hit with a challenge on Sam Whitelock to earn a red card of his own. Both Rennie and Wallabies captain Michael Hooper accepted Swinton’s dismissal. “We don’t train to tackle around the head and we have to talk about player safety ... we want players playing as long as we possibly can in this game,” Hooper said. “If that’s the interpretation from up top, we’ve got to be better and tackle lower.” Then, winger Marika Koroibete was yellow-carded for a line-ball penalty deemed the final straw following repeated infringements. Nonetheless, they defied their short-term shortage after the break, and Hodge’s penalty converted early pressure into an 11-8 lead. It was all too fleeting. All Blacks hooker Codie Taylor scored off the back of the scrum from the restart and an immediate reply went begging when Nic White fumbled Wright’s inside pass. Hodge then missed a penalty from 50m but the Wallabies continued to press, and New Zealand’s Scott Barrett was sin-binned for a professional foul. He did not miss another from in front, though, slotting a curtain-raiser for Tupou’s next act. Vaa’i had been foraging for late sustenance, and his try fashioned a sliver of hope for Ian Foster’s outfit. Koroibete put that idea to bed via a flying hit on Damian McKenzie, to restore some pride after a 2-1 series loss featuring one win, one draw and two defeats. “We said we wanted a response after last weekend and we got it,” Rennie said post-match. “Hodgey kicked pretty well and we got our noses in front. We’ve got a long way to go – we’re going to get much better – But it’s good to get a result like this. It helps to get a bit of belief.” James Slipper left his 100th Test early with an arm injury.
